{"uri": "8208165448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:26:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:26:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T16:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://www.local3news.com/local-news/president-biden-to-award-medal-of-honor-to-union-soldiers-who-helped-hijack-train-in/article_f50c29ec-3936-11ef-8850-ef2fd3142812.html", "title": "President Biden to award Medal of Honor to Union soldiers who helped hijack train in Confederate territory", "body": "UPDATE: President Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry on Wednesday to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles (140 kilometers) as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nPREVIOUS STORY: The last two members of the Great Locomotive Chase of 1862 will receive the Medal of Honor on July 3.\n\nPrivates Philip Shadrach and George Wilson were a part of a Union group of volunteers who took control of a Confederate train outside of modern-day Kennesaw on April 12, 1862.\n\nThe group's mission was to destroy vital Confederate railroad and telegraph lines on their way to Chattanooga.\n\nEight of the 22 volunteers led by James J. Andrews were hanged after being caught by Confederate soldiers.\n\nOf the eligible soldiers, Shadrach and Wilson are now the last two to receive the medals 162 years after their execution.\n\nThe White House's ceremony to present the Medal of Honor to the families of Shadrach and Wilson is scheduled for 5:15pm on July 3.\n\nThe Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center is celebrating the White House's announcement of Biden's plans to recognize the two soldiers.\n\nDavid Currey, executive director of the center, say the decision to award Shadrach and Wilson corrects a historical oversight.\n\nBiden will bestow Medal of Honor on Union soldiers who helped hijack train in Confederate territory\n\nPresident Joe Biden is awarding the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines. U.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden on Wednesday is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration. Shadrach was from Pennsylvania and was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. Wilson was from Ohio and worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war.\n\n\"It also created the first of several undeniable historical connections between Chattanooga and the Medal of Honor that ultimately established Chattanooga as the Birthplace of the Medal of Honor,\" Currey said.\n\nTo learn more about the Andrews Raid and the Great Locomotive Chase, you can visit the Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center, located in downtown Chattanooga at the Aquarium Plaza, or navigate to their website.", "source": {"uri": "local3news.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local3News.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@local3news.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Locomotive_Chase", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Great Locomotive Chase"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Union (American Civil War)"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medal_of_Honor", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Medal of Honor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telegraphy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Telegraphy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Confederate States of America"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Civil_War", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "American Civil War"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Andrews", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "James J. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nMore from this section\n\nSimone Biles headlines a U.S. women's gymnastics team eyeing redemption Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape US politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tenn.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Ga., and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Will Weissert of The Associated Press.\n\nGerald Taylor, the great great nephew of Pvt. Philip G. Shadrach, departs after a Medal of Honor ceremony Wednesday at the White House in Washington, posthumously honoring two U.S. Army privates who were part of a daring Union Army contingent that stole a Confederate train during the Civil War. {"uri": "2024-07-411172741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "11:34:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T11:34:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T07:31:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/4/biden-awards-posthumous-medal-of-honor-on-forgotte/", "title": "Biden bestows Medal of Honor on Union soldiers who helped hijack train in Confederate territory", "body": "President Joe Biden on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\nPHOTOS: Biden bestows Medal of Honor on Union soldiers who helped hijack train in Confederate territory\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, {"uri": "8207438472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "09:05:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T09:05:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T09:04:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3004689-medal-of-honor-awarded-posthumously-to-civil-war-heroes", "title": "Medal of Honor Awarded Posthumously to Civil War Heroes | Politics", "body": "President Joe Biden will posthumously award the Medal of Honor to U.S. Army privates Philip Shadrach and George Wilson for their bravery during the Great Locomotive Chase of the Civil War. These men, part of a Union Army contingent that stole a Confederate train, were not recognized until now.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden on Wednesday will award the Medal of Honor posthumously to two U.S. Army privates who were part of a daring Union Army contingent that stole a Confederate train during the Civil War, the White House said.\n\nPhilip Shadrach and George Wilson, will receive the medals during a White House ceremony that will recognize their \"gallantry and intrepidity\" during what become known as the Great Locomotive Chase, one of the earliest special operations in U.S. Army history, the White House said. The operation, which took place 200 miles (322 km) behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862, saw Union Soldiers dressed as civilians hijack a train in Georgia and drive it north into Tennessee for 87 miles, placing explosives on the track behind them as they headed north to destroy Confederate infrastructure.\n\nSix of those participants became the Army's first recipients of the then-newly created Medal of Honor. Over the next two decades, another 13 members were recognized for their role in mission, but Shadrach and Wilson, who were both hanged for their actions after being captured, were never recognized until now. The White House ceremony offers Biden a brief respite from mounting criticism from some of his fellow Democrats after his shaky and halting performance in last week's presidential debate against Republican former President Donald Trump.\n\nThe mission saw 24 men infiltrate the South in small groups, rendezvousing north of Atlanta at Marietta, Georgia. On the day the operation was executed, 22 of the men commandeered a locomotive known as \"The General\" and proceeded north, tearing up railroad tracks and cutting telegraph wires as they went. Shadrach, a native Pennsylvanian orphaned at an early age, was only 21 years old when he volunteered for the dangerous mission. Wilson, born in Ohio, was a journeyman shoemaker who enlisted in the Union Army in August 1861.\n\nThe White House said it was not clear why Shadrach and Wilson were not originally recommended for the Medal of Honor. The Medal of Honor is awarded to members of the armed forces who show great personal bravery or self-sacrifice and distinguish themselves at the risk of their own lives while engaged in military Buy a Day Pass or just this story using our new Digital Wallet\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry on Wednesday to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles (140 kilometers) as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. {"uri": "2024-07-410559492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "22:28:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T22:28:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T21:23:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/biden-bestows-medal-of-honor-on-union-soldiers-who-helped-hijack-train-in-confederate-territory/article_908b473d-6769-542c-93c2-b9e0aba98ffc.html", "title": "Biden bestows Medal of Honor on Union soldiers who helped hijack train in Confederate territory", "body": "President Joe Biden speaks during a Medal of Honor Ceremony at the White House in Washington, Wednesday, July 3, 2024, posthumously honoring two U.S. Army privates who were part of a daring Union Army contingent that stole a Confederate train during the Civil War. U.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles (140 kilometers) as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nAssociated Press writer Will Weissert contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. The president is recognizing their courage 162 years later.\n\nPresident Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry on Wednesday to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. {"uri": "2024-07-410216387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "15:16:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T15:16:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.wisn.com/article/medal-of-honor-civil-war-heroes/61498791", "title": "Biden will bestow the Medal of Honor on 2 Civil War heroes who helped hijack a train in confederacy", "body": "President Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry on Wednesday to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.U.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.The posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.Biden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.Shadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.A Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.On April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.Confederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.The first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.The government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.Shadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.Wilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.The Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nPresident Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry on Wednesday to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 service members -- both Union and Confederate -- between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as \"the Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called \"Andrews' Raiders\" met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named \"The General.\" The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor award ever bestowed went to Private Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nBorn on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, Shadrach was just 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking entitled \"The Great Locomotive Chase\" that starred Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General\" starring Buster Keaton was also based on the historic event.\n\nMore from this section\n\nCenterpoint Appoints Galen Baggs as New Chief Operating Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 service members -- both Union and Confederate -- between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as \"the Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called \"Andrews' Raiders\" met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named \"The General.\" The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor award ever bestowed went to Private Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nBorn on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, Shadrach was just 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking entitled \"The Great Locomotive Chase\" that starred Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called \"Andrews' Raiders\" met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named \"The General.\" The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor award ever bestowed went to Private Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nBorn on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, Shadrach was just 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking entitled \"The Great Locomotive Chase\" that starred Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. George D. Wilson in the East Room at the White House in Washington, Wednesday, July 3, 2024. The medals posthumously honor two U.S. Army privates who were part of a daring Union Army contingent that stole a Confederate train during the Civil War. U.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. At left is Gerald Taylor, the great great nephew of Pvt. Philip G. Shadrach.\n\nBy Josh Boak, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, July 3, 2024 | 2:24 p.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles (140 kilometers) as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\n__\n\nAssociated Press writer Will Weissert contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-410535646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "21:44:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T21:44:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T21:29:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/us/medal-honor-biden-civil-war-locomotive/2024/07/03/id/1171185/", "title": "Biden Bestows Medal of Honor on Union Soldiers Who Hijacked Train in Confederate Territory", "body": "President Joe Biden on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles (140 kilometers) as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. {"uri": "2024-07-409797423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "09:31:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T09:31:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T05:06:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-07-03/biden-to-bestow-medal-of-honor-on-two-civil-war-heroes-who-helped-hijack-a-train-in-confederacy", "title": "Biden to Bestow Medal of Honor on Two Civil War Heroes Who Helped Hijack a Train in Confederacy", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden will award the Medal of Honor on Wednesday for \"conspicuous gallantry\" to a pair of Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the American Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Privates Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 service members -- both Union and Confederate -- between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as \"the Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called \"Andrews' Raiders\" met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named \"The General.\" The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor award ever bestowed went to Private Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nBorn on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, Shadrach was just 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking entitled \"The Great Locomotive Chase\" that starred Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General\" starring Buster Keaton was also based on the historic event.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden is recognizing their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration.\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden, a Democrat, has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8209165090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "08:42:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T08:42:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T08:37:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/union-heroes-honored-for-daring-mission/article_f650f811-98cc-5e46-9554-c6cb00f4e501.html", "title": "Union heroes honored for daring mission", "body": "Biden awards Medal of Honor to soldiers who stole train deep in Confederate territory JOSH BOAK\n\nAssociated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor for conspicuous gallantry to two Union soldiers who stole a locomotive deep in Confederate territory during the Civil War and drove it north for 87 miles as they destroyed railroad tracks and telegraph lines.\n\nU.S. Army Pvts. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nPeople are also reading... Child shot while playing at Waterloo's Lafayette Park Sunday night John Deere closes on land for 1.2 million-square-foot Indiana warehouse NAME RELEASED: 2 Waterloo officers shot, suspect killed in Sunday shooting Deere has laid off nearly 1,000 since September, more expected today Several vehicles in 58 and Ridgeway crash Walnut Ridge Baptist Church plans move to new building, site plan change coming to council Patton Diner serving both unique and familiar dishes in Cedar Falls John Deere announces 600+ layoffs at East Moline, Davenport and Dubuque Drivers urged to slow down or steer clear of construction zone Appointment of Waterloo police chief met with hesitation after officer involved shooting Suspect who shot two officers had spent time in prison for ramming a squad car in 2014 Firecracker Fourth of July celebrations planned throughout Cedar Valley College Football: UNI OC departs program, Panthers add coach to staff Man arrested in store robbery Minnesota man arrested for stealing purse from Cedar Falls vehicle\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riff ed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the Union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-greatgreat-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded.\n\nThey were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohiobased volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOkoboji lakes remain at near record levels; water activities still curtailed as July 4 holiday nears Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Sergeant Bluff-Luton assistant principal, AD resigns days after being placed on administrative leave Where to go for firework displays in Siouxland McCook Lake faces questions of flood recovery, future mitigation Dairy plant sues Sanborn over loss of $4 million in cheese What to know before you go to Saturday in the Park 2024 Siouxland homes without flood insurance face coverage limits and costly repairs after flooding OUR OPINION: Noem erred by not having National Guard help with S.D. flooding High school baseball top performers: East's Colling, RSM's Loucks, MOC's McCarty drive teams' push Noem: North Sioux 'tried to make the best decision' to protect homes, families Cherokee residents try to stave off despair by jumping into action after flood Saturday in the Park continues to bring in big name acts without charging admission Some McCook Lake residents allowed access to flooded homes McCook Lake residents voice their flooding concerns to Sen. Mike Rounds\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democrac since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the Union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded.\n\nThey were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet
