Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the Union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded.\n\nThey were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohiobased volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. Philip G. Shadrach and George D. Wilson were captured by Confederates and executed by hanging. Biden recognized their courage 162 years later with the country's highest military decoration, calling the operation they joined \"one of the most dangerous missions of the entire Civil War.\"\n\n\"Every soldier who joined that mission was awarded the Medal of Honor except for two. Two soldiers who died because of that operation and never received this recognition,\" Biden said. \"Today, we right that wrong.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse men face felony charges for Onalaska storage unit break-in New River Point District agreement leaves only one lot unclaimed for $300M La Crosse development La Crosse police investigate fatal car crash Steve Cahalan: Sushi Pirate opens Monday with new owner and expanded menu UPDATE: Flooding shuts down Pettibone Park and marsh trails, but Riverfest firework show set to continue in La Crosse Why does Kwik Trip have a cult following in Wisconsin? Riverfest, campers impacted by high water as Mississippi River rises in La Crosse and Winona Holmen man, Bangor woman arrested for intent to deliver meth Police arrest 13-year-old tied to one of two recent La Crosse shooting incidents Second person charged in trafficking of teen girl in La Crosse area Steve Cahalan: Tasty Thai to replace Il Luigi Italian Cuisine restaurant in Onalaska Work begins in earnest on new downtown Winona hotel, housing project Vernon County gears up for Independence Day celebrations UPDATE: La Crosse closes Pettibone Park until further notice Minnesota man charged with drug trafficking, lewd behavior in La Crosse County\n\nThe posthumous recognition comes as the legacy of the Civil War, which killed more than 600,000 Union and Confederate service members between 1861 and 1865, continues to shape U.S. politics in a contentious election year in which issues of race, constitutional rights and presidential power are at the forefront.\n\nBiden has said that the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald Trump was the greatest threat to democracy since the Civil War. Meanwhile, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, riffed at a recent Pennsylvania rally about the Battle of Gettysburg and about the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe president said Wednesday that Shadrach and Wilson were \"fighting and even dying to preserve the Union and the sacred values it was founded upon: freedom, justice, fairness, unity.\"\n\n\"Phillip and George were willing to shed their blood to make these ideals real,\" Biden said.\n\nTheresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, recalled for The Associated Press how the Union soldier had the noose around his neck on the gallows and spoke his final words.\n\nShe said that Wilson essentially said that he was there to serve his country and had no ill feelings for the people of the South, but that he hoped for the abolition of slavery and for the nation to be united again.\n\n\"When I read that, I had chills,\" Chandler said. \"We can feel that as a family and that we're enjoying our freedoms today, what he tried to move forward at the time.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBrian Taylor, a great-great-great-nephew of Shadrach, said this was an opportunity for his ancestor to be remembered as \"a brave soldier who did what he thought was right.\"\n\n\"I kind of feel that he was a bit adventurous, a bit of a free spirit,\" Taylor said.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are being recognized for participating in what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase.\n\nA Kentucky-born civilian spy and scout named James J. Andrews put together a group of volunteers, including Shadrach and Wilson, to degrade the railway and telegraph lines used by Confederates in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nOn April 12, 1862, 22 of the men in what was later called Andrews' Raiders met up in Marietta, Georgia, and hijacked a train named The General. The group tore up tracks and sliced through telegraph wires while taking the train north.\n\nConfederate troops chased them, initially on foot and later by train. The Confederate troops eventually caught the group. Andrews and seven others were executed, while the others either escaped or remained prisoners of war.\n\nThe first Medal of Honor ever bestowed went to Pvt. Jacob Parrott, who participated in the locomotive hijacking and was beaten while imprisoned by the Confederacy.\n\nThe government later recognized 18 other participants who took part in the raid with the honor, but Shadrach and Wilson were excluded. They were later authorized to receive the medal as part of the fiscal 2008 National Defense Authorization Act.\n\nShadrach, born on Sept. 15, 1840, in Pennsylvania, was 21 years old when he volunteered for the mission. He was orphaned at a young age and left home in 1861 to enlist in an Ohio infantry regiment after the start of the Civil War.\n\nWilson was born in 1830 in Belmont County, Ohio. He worked as a journeyman shoemaker before the war and enlisted in an Ohio-based volunteer infantry in 1861.\n\nThe Walt Disney Corp. made a 1956 movie about the hijacking titled \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" starring Fess Parker and Jeffrey Hunter. The 1926 silent film \"The General,\" starring Buster Keaton, was also based on the historic event.\n\nA timeline of the Civil War A timeline of the Civil War Lincoln calls in troops to contain the {"uri": "2024-07-410315028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:49:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:49:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:25:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2024/07/03/medal-of-honor-civil-war-soldiers/74290480007/", "title": "Biden fixes 161-year-old oversight, awards Medal of Honor to 2 Civil War soldiers", "body": "On April 12, 1862, a group of Union soldiers stole a locomotive in Georgia and rode it north, destroying track and telegraph lines in their wake.\n\nThe plan, masterminded by Kentucky civilian scout James J. Andrews, was to cut off Chattanooga, Tennessee, from the Confederacy by destroying the railroad tracks, bridges and telegraph lines that connected the city to Atlanta. Twenty-two Union soldiers from Ohio regiments and another civilian joined the plot, which involved sneaking into the South wearing civilian clothes.\n\nOn March 25, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln's war secretary bestowed the group that became known as Andrews' Raiders with the country's first Medals of Honor. In the years since, all but two soldiers involved in the raid have received the nation's highest military decoration for their bravery.\n\n\"Privates (Philip G.) Shadrach and (George D.) Wilson heroically served our nation during the Civil War, making the ultimate sacrifice of their lives to protect the Union, but because of a clerical error, they never received the Medal of Honor they each deserved,\" Sen. Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, said in a statement.\n\nOn Wednesday, President Joe Biden will fix the 161-year-old oversight by posthumously honoring Shadrach and Wilson, who were hanged for the heist.\n\nThe Great Locomotive Chase\n\nShadrach was born in Somerset County, Pennsylvania, on Sept. 15, 1840, to Robert and Elizabeth Shadrach, and became an orphan at an early age. Shadrach enlisted in the 2nd Ohio Infantry Regiment in 1861 and volunteered for the dangerous mission at age 21.\n\n\"Like many other young volunteer soldiers, Private Shadrach was willing to encounter both peril and hardship to fight for what he believed in,\" according to a White House news release.\n\nWilson was born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1830 to George and Elizabeth Wilson. Originally a craftsman, Wilson volunteered for the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry in 1861 and joined Andrews' Raiders shortly after.\n\nOnce Shadrach, Wilson and the others arrived in Georgia, they commandeered a locomotive called \"The General\" and its three boxcars. They stole the train while the crew and passengers were eating breakfast at the Lacy Hotel in Big Shanty, Georgia. The train's conductor chased them, first on foot and later by handcar for 87 miles, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nThe pursuit continued for until about 18 miles from Chattanooga, where the Union soldiers abandoned the \"General\" and fled. They were caught, and eight men were later executed by hanging, including Andrews, Shadrach and Wilson.\n\nOne of the Raiders wrote about the operation and in 1956, Walt Disney Productions released a film about the event called \"The Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nIn 2007, former Ohio Rep. Dave Hobson introduced legislation to correct the omission of Shadrach and Wilson's medals after a constituent brought the issue to his attention. The following year, Congress authorized honoring the men - but it never happened.\n\n\"These gentlemen were left out. They performed the same heroic acts,\" Hobson said in an interview. \"I thought this is not right. We're going to try to fix this. Finally, we're getting it fixed in my lifetime.\"\n\nBogged down in bureaucracy, the honor was never bestowed. Brown's office took up the mantle in 2015 to recognize the men's bravery and sacrifice.\n\nBrown asked Biden in an October 2023 letter to \"correct this wrong\" and award the soldiers the Medal of Honor. \"It is past time to acknowledge the bravery and meritorious action of Privates Shadrach and Wilson, as well as their sacrifice in defense of the Union.\"\n\nAnd on July 3, 2024, Shadrach and Wilson's time finally came.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Locomotive_Chase", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Great Locomotive Chase"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Union (American Civil War)"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medal_of_Honor", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Medal of Honor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telegraphy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Telegraphy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotive", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Locomotive"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Civil_War", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "American Civil War"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Georgia (U.S. state)"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Georgia (U.S. state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2nd_Ohio_Infantry_Regiment", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "2nd Ohio Infantry Regiment"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Andrews", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "James J. {"uri": "2024-07-410322357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:55:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:55:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:37:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.wtva.com/news/two-union-soldiers-to-posthumously-receive-medal-of-honor-for-carrying-out-daring-mission-behind/article_dab8b6df-19ad-5d7c-b54f-e2703f9e5d3a.html", "title": "Two Union soldiers to posthumously receive Medal of Honor for carrying out daring mission behind Confederate lines", "body": "In this illustration provided by the US Army, Union soldiers cut telegraph wires and commandeered a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga in April 1862. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\"\n\n(CNN) -- Two Union soldiers from the American Civil War are being posthumously awarded with the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on Wednesday, more than 160 years after being executed for their part in a daring mission against the Confederacy.\n\n\"Private Philip G. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson will receive the Medal of Honor posthumously for their gallantry and intrepidity while participating in a covert military operation 200 miles behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862,\" a White House official said. \"In one of the earliest special operations in US Army history, Union Soldiers dressed as civilians infiltrated the Confederacy, hijacked a train in Georgia and drove it north for 87 miles, destroying enemy infrastructure along the way.\"\n\nBiden will award the medals in a ceremony at the White House with descendants of Shadrach and Wilson expected to attend.\n\nThe pair were members of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment in 1862 when they joined 20 other Union soldiers, and two civilians, to infiltrate Confederate territory.\n\nThe raid, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, involved the soldiers commandeering a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\" The Confederates began chasing the General in handcars and locomotives, at some points even on foot, eventually catching up to them and forcing the Union soldiers to abandon it.\n\nThey were all captured within two weeks, and found guilty of \"acts of unlawful belligerency,\" according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nDr. Shane Makowicki, a US Army historian and expert in the American Civil War, told reporters that both Shadrach and Wilson were convicted as spies, and then executed by hanging.\n\n\"This is absolutely [a story] of intense dedication and commitment, intense bravery and comradery amongst the group of men that had only known each other for a short time, who believed in the mission and believed in the sacrifice and what they were doing to preserve the union,\" Kim Chandler, Wilson's great-great-great-granddaughter, told reporters on Tuesday.\n\nThe operation is now known as the Great Locomotive Chase. While other members of the raid received the Medal of Honor sooner -- six of whom after being released in a prisoner exchange in 1863 -- Brad Quinlan, another historian who assisted in the effort to get Shadrach and Wilson recognized, said bad timing was primarily to blame for the delay in Shadrach and Wilson's recognition. In the aftermath of the raid, he said, their officers were promoted into different units and moved on.\n\n\"It was just at that moment during our history, nobody was there to stand up for them and move this through, even their comrades who made the visits to Chattanooga and dedicated the monument to the Great Locomotive Chase in 1890, I don't think they even realized that these two men never had the medal. The paperwork never got through,\" Quinlan said.\n\n\"There was nothing anywhere in any of my research, any documentation that said these men did not do what the others have done,\" he added. \"Their bravery, their dignity, and their dedication to the Republic was exactly the same.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, Shadrach's great-great-great-nephew, told reporters the posthumous award is the culmination of \"a lot of very hard work\" for his family -- including efforts by his father to contact President Jimmy Carter.\n\n\"He was sending stuff to Jimmy Carter years ago, sometimes getting information back and sometimes getting ignored,\" Taylor said.\n\nQuinlan said he was pulled into the fight to get Shadrach and Wilson medals in April 2012 by Ron Shadrach, a great cousin of the Civil War private. It took 12 years of \"researching, finding new documents, primary sources, and submitting the documentation,\" he said.\n\n\"It was just something that needed to be done,\" Ron Shadrach said.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8207536774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "10:05:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T10:05:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T10:05:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/ohio-regiment-soldiers-receive-medal-090901913.html", "title": "Ohio regiment soldiers receive Medal of Honor for Civil War locomotive chase", "body": "On April 12, 1862, a group of Union soldiers from Ohio regiments stole a locomotive in Georgia and rode it north, destroying track and telegraph lines in their wake.\n\nThe plan, masterminded by Kentucky civilian scout James J. Andrews, was to cut off Chattanooga, Tenn. from the Confederacy by destroying the railroad tracks, bridges and telegraph lines that connected the city to Atlanta. Twenty-two Union soldiers from Ohio regiments and another civilian joined the plot, which involved sneaking into the South wearing civilian clothes.\n\nOn March 25, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln's war secretary bestowed Andrews' Raiders with the country's first Medals of Honor. In the years since, all but two soldiers involved in the raid have received the nation's highest military decoration for their bravery.\n\n\"Privates (Philip G.) Shadrach and (George D.) Wilson heroically served our nation during the Civil War, making the ultimate sacrifice of their lives to protect the Union, but because of a clerical error, they never received the Medal of Honor they each deserved,\" Sen. Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, said in a statement.\n\nOn Wednesday, President Joe Biden will fix the 161-year-old oversight by honoring Private Philip G. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson posthumously.\n\nShadrach was born in Somerset County, Pennsylvania, on September 15, 1840, to Robert and Elizabeth Shadrach, and became an orphan at an early age. Shadrach enlisted in the 2nd Ohio Infantry Regiment in 1861 and volunteered for the dangerous mission at age 21.\n\n\"Like many other young volunteer soldiers, Private Shadrach was willing to encounter both peril and hardship to fight for what he believed in,\" according to a White House news release.\n\nWilson was born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1830 to George and Elizabeth Wilson. Originally a craftsman, Wilson volunteered for the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry in 1861 and joined Andrews' Raiders shortly after.\n\nOnce Shadrach, Wilson and the others arrived in Georgia, they commandeered a locomotive called \"The General\" and its three boxcars. They stole the train while the crew and passengers were eating breakfast at the Lacy Hotel in Big Shanty, Georgia. The train's conductor chased them, first on foot and later by handcar for 87 miles, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nThe pursuit continued for until about 18 miles from Chattanooga, where the Union soldiers abandoned the \"General\" and fled. They were caught and eight men were later executed by hanging, including Andrews, Shadrach and Wilson.\n\nOne of the raiders wrote about the operation and in 1956, Walt Disney Productions released a film about the event called \"The Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nFor years, Ron Shadrach, a second cousin several times removed of Private Shadrach, has campaigned to honor the two soldiers.\n\nIn 2007, former U.S. Rep. Dave Hobson, R-Springfield, introduced legislation to correct the omission of Shadrach and Wilson's medals. A constituent from Amanda brought the issue to his attention. The following year, Congress authorized honoring the men - but it never happened.\n\n\"These gentlemen were left out. They performed the same heroic acts,\" Hobson said in an interview. \"I thought this is not right. We're going to try to fix this. Finally, we're getting it fixed in my lifetime.\"\n\nBogged down in bureaucracy, the honor was never bestowed. Brown's office took up the mantle in 2015 to recognize the men's bravery and sacrifice.\n\nBrown asked Biden in an October 2023 letter to \"correct this wrong\" and award the soldiers the Medal of Honor. \"It is past time to acknowledge the bravery and meritorious action of Privates Shadrach and Wilson, as well as their sacrifice in defense of the Union.\"\n\nAnd on July 3, 2024, Shadrach and Wilson's time finally came.\n\nJessie Balmert is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated {"uri": "2024-07-410322126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:55:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:55:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:50:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.aol.com/biden-award-medal-honor-civil-155011328.html", "title": "Biden to award Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later", "body": "Biden to award Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later\n\nCHRIS BOCCIA and NATE LUNA\n\nJuly 3, 2024 at 5:50 PM\n\nTwo Union soldiers who 162 years ago took part in one of America's first special operations will be posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor on Wednesday.\n\nDescendants of Pvt. George Wilson and Pvt. Shadrach received a long-awaited call from the White House telling them the Civil War heroes would be awarded the nation's highest military honor for \"gallantry and intrepidity\" in defense of the Union.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was on the other line, they said, inviting Theresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Pvt. Wilson, and Gerald Taylor, the great-great-nephew of Pvt. Shadrach, to accept the medal on behalf of the men who, as a part of a group of 24 volunteers, snuck behind Confederate lines in an act of unprecedented bravery.\n\nThe Union soldiers -- acting as spies in civilian clothing -- managed to penetrate 200 miles into Confederate territory, where they commandeered a train -- \"The General\" -- and drove it 87 miles from Georgia to Tennessee.\n\nIn what became known as \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" on April 12, 1862, the Union raiders destroyed Confederate railroad tracks and telegraph lines -- earned 19 of the men Medals of Honor, becoming the first group of Army soldiers to receive it.\n\nThe ambitious plot, despite wreaking havoc, failed. The soldiers were captured. Some escaped and received their medals after the war, while a group of eight of the raiders -- including Wilson and Shadrach -- were tried and hanged by the Confederacy.\n\nBecause of what historians attribute to an oversight, Wilson and Shadrach never received the award posthumously.\n\nRon Shadrach, a descendant of Pvt. Shadrach, who was only 21 when he volunteered for the mission, and historian Brad Quinlon, teamed up to push Shadrach and Wilson's case. Text from a 2008 act of Congress even cleared the way for Wilson and Shadrach to be honored, but for reasons resembling \"red tape,\" some family said, the call simply never came.\n\nShadrach and Quinlon met in 2012 and made their case for 12 years, but even before them, a relative of Pvt. Shadrach was sending letters to President Jimmy Carter.\n\nAt the outset of the Biden Administration, two former generals -- one a four-star -- joined Shadrach and Quinlon's efforts.\n\nQuinlon believes the clandestine mission, which the White House describes as one of the first special operations in United States history, if successful, would have shortened the Civil War by as long as two years.\n\n\"I mean these were common citizens -- a laborer, a carpenter,\" he said.\n\n\"They enlisted. They weren't drafted; they enlisted voluntarily. And then all of a sudden you're getting the word, you know, we're asking for volunteers to come do what? Go in to a hundred miles of Confederate territory to steal a train. They stayed on. They were given a chance, they could have left after that, but they stayed on.\"\n\n\"I guess, unless we've really done it, do we really know what courage that took?\"\n\nBefore they were hanged, Pvt. Wilson is reported to have given a brief speech from the gallows in which he said he did not regret his action to help save the Union.\n\n\"He proclaimed that they would yet see the flag of the United States wave over them again,\" Ron Shadrack said.\n\nTwo years later, they would.\n\nShadrack labored over the case for more than 12 years to rectify the historical record, but, above all, he said, he did so in service of his ancestor's sacrifices.\n\n\"We can't really comprehend what they went through,\" the Ohio native said, a bout of imprisonment that including lashing and torture.\n\n\"I had wanted to serve my country, and I hadn't,\" Shadrack said. \"And so now I've been able to do this...\" he said, choking up, seemingly reckoning with this moment - a present day that would pay tribute to a day 162 years ago for which he has so long fought.\n\n\"And I think it's, it's something that any ordinary American would do,\" he said. \"It's what we do.\"\n\nQuinlon, who in his work has studied the acts of Medal of Honor recipients, said the award -- given to some 3,500 warfighters in U.S. history -- has documented the American story on the battlefield.\n\n\"I wouldn't have taken the project on if I didn't feel it was the right thing to do. I understand the Medal of Honor. I understand where it stands today with our military. And every military person looks up to a Medal of Honor recipients. Even generals take a seat to a Medal of Honor recipient,\" he said.\n\nA future Medal of Honor recipient saved Quinlon's father's life in the Philippines in World War II, losing his life as he fought off the Japanese.\n\n\"I am here because of what William Shockley did on March 31st, 1945. I understand the valor and sacrifice of the Medal of Honor,\" Quinlon said.\n\nBiden to award Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later originally appeared on abcnews.go.com", "source": {"uri": "8208088731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "15:37:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T15:37:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:34:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/biden-fixes-161-old-oversight-152554460.html", "title": "Biden fixes 161-year-old oversight, awards Medal of Honor to 2 Civil War soldiers", "body": "On April 12, 1862, a group of Union soldiers stole a locomotive in Georgia and rode it north, destroying track and telegraph lines in their wake.\n\nThe plan, masterminded by Kentucky civilian scout James J. Andrews, was to cut off Chattanooga, Tennessee, from the Confederacy by destroying the railroad tracks, bridges and telegraph lines that connected the city to Atlanta. Twenty-two Union soldiers from Ohio regiments and another civilian joined the plot, which involved sneaking into the South wearing civilian clothes.\n\nOn March 25, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln's war secretary bestowed the group that became known as Andrews' Raiders with the country's first Medals of Honor. In the years since, all but two soldiers involved in the raid have received the nation's highest military decoration for their bravery.\n\n\"Privates (Philip G.) Shadrach and (George D.) Wilson heroically served our nation during the Civil War, making the ultimate sacrifice of their lives to protect the Union, but because of a clerical error, they never received the Medal of Honor they each deserved,\" Sen. Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, said in a statement.\n\nOn Wednesday, President Joe Biden will fix the 161-year-old oversight by posthumously honoring Shadrach and Wilson, who were hanged for the heist.\n\nShadrach was born in Somerset County, Pennsylvania, on Sept. 15, 1840, to Robert and Elizabeth Shadrach, and became an orphan at an early age. Shadrach enlisted in the 2nd Ohio Infantry Regiment in 1861 and volunteered for the dangerous mission at age 21.\n\n\"Like many other young volunteer soldiers, Private Shadrach was willing to encounter both peril and hardship to fight for what he believed in,\" according to a White House news release.\n\nWilson was born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1830 to George and Elizabeth Wilson. Originally a craftsman, Wilson volunteered for the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry in 1861 and joined Andrews' Raiders shortly after.\n\nOnce Shadrach, Wilson and the others arrived in Georgia, they commandeered a locomotive called \"The General\" and its three boxcars. They stole the train while the crew and passengers were eating breakfast at the Lacy Hotel in Big Shanty, Georgia. The train's conductor chased them, first on foot and later by handcar for 87 miles, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nThe pursuit continued for until about 18 miles from Chattanooga, where the Union soldiers abandoned the \"General\" and fled. They were caught, and eight men were later executed by hanging, including Andrews, Shadrach and Wilson.\n\nOne of the Raiders wrote about the operation and in 1956, Walt Disney Productions released a film about the event called \"The Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nFor years, Ron Shadrach, a second cousin several times removed from Private Shadrach, has campaigned to honor the two soldiers.\n\nIn 2007, former Ohio Rep. Dave Hobson introduced legislation to correct the omission of Shadrach and Wilson's medals after a constituent brought the issue to his attention. The following year, Congress authorized honoring the men - but it never happened.\n\n\"These gentlemen were left out. They performed the same heroic acts,\" Hobson said in an interview. \"I thought this is not right. We're going to try to fix this. Finally, we're getting it fixed in my lifetime.\"\n\nBogged down in bureaucracy, the honor was never bestowed. Brown's office took up the mantle in 2015 to recognize the men's bravery and sacrifice.\n\nBrown asked Biden in an October 2023 letter to \"correct this wrong\" and award the soldiers the Medal of Honor. \"It is past time to acknowledge the bravery and meritorious action of Privates Shadrach and Wilson, as well as their sacrifice in defense of the Union.\"\n\nAnd on July 3, 2024, Shadrach and Wilson's time finally came.\n\nJessie Balmert is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated Shadrach, to accept the medal on behalf of the men who, as a part of a group of 24 volunteers, snuck behind Confederate lines in an act of unprecedented bravery.\n\nThe Union soldiers -- acting as spies in civilian clothing -- managed to penetrate 200 miles into Confederate territory, where they commandeered a train -- \"The General\" -- and drove it 87 miles from Georgia to Tennessee.\n\nIn what became known as \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" on April 12, 1862, the Union raiders destroyed Confederate railroad tracks and telegraph lines -- earned 19 of the men Medals of Honor, becoming the first group of Army soldiers to receive it.\n\nThe ambitious plot, despite wreaking havoc, failed. The soldiers were captured. Some escaped and received their medals after the war, while a group of eight of the raiders -- including Wilson and Shadrach -- were tried and hanged by the Confederacy.\n\nBecause of what historians attribute to an oversight, Wilson and Shadrach never received the award posthumously.\n\nRon Shadrach, a descendant of Pvt. Shadrach, who was only 21 when he volunteered for the mission, and historian Brad Quinlon, teamed up to push Shadrach and Wilson's case. Text from a 2008 act of Congress even cleared the way for Wilson and Shadrach to be honored, but for reasons resembling \"red tape,\" some family said, the call simply never came.\n\nShadrach and Quinlon met in 2012 and made their case for 12 years, but even before them, a relative of Pvt. Shadrach was sending letters to President Jimmy Carter.\n\nAt the outset of the Biden Administration, two former generals -- one a four-star -- joined Shadrach and Quinlon's efforts.\n\nQuinlon believes the clandestine mission, which the White House describes as one of the first special operations in United States history, if successful, would have shortened the Civil War by as long as two years.\n\n\"I mean these were common citizens -- a laborer, a carpenter,\" he said.\n\n\"They enlisted. They weren't drafted; they enlisted voluntarily. And then all of a sudden you're getting the word, you know, we're asking for volunteers to come do what? Go in to a hundred miles of Confederate territory to steal a train. They stayed on. They were given a chance, they could have left after that, but they stayed on.\"\n\n\"I guess, unless we've really done it, do we really know what courage that took?\"\n\nBefore they were hanged, Pvt. Wilson is reported to have given a brief speech from the gallows in which he said he did not regret his action to help save the Union.\n\n\"He proclaimed that they would yet see the flag of the United States wave over them again,\" Ron Shadrack said.\n\nTwo years later, they would.\n\nShadrack labored over the case for more than 12 years to rectify the historical record, but, above all, he said, he did so in service of his ancestor's sacrifices.\n\n\"We can't really comprehend what they went through,\" the Ohio native said, a bout of imprisonment that including lashing and torture.\n\n\"I had wanted to serve my country, and I hadn't,\" Shadrack said. \"And so now I've been able to do this...\" he said, choking up, seemingly reckoning with this moment - a present day that would pay tribute to a day 162 years ago for which he has so long fought.\n\n\"And I think it's, it's something that any ordinary American would do,\" he said. \"It's what we do.\"\n\nQuinlon, who in his work has studied the acts of Medal of Honor recipients, said the award -- given to some 3,500 warfighters in U.S. history -- has documented the American story on the battlefield.\n\n\"I wouldn't have taken the project on if I didn't feel it was the right thing to do. I understand the Medal of Honor. I understand where it stands today with our military. And every military person looks up to a Medal of Honor recipients. Even generals take a seat to a Medal of Honor recipient,\" he said.\n\nA future Medal of Honor recipient saved Quinlon's father's life in the Philippines in World War II, losing his life as he fought off the Japanese.\n\n\"I am here because of what William Shockley did on March 31st, 1945. I understand the valor and sacrifice of the Medal of Honor,\" Quinlon said.", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8208138143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T16:08:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://keyt.com/politics/cnn-us-politics/2024/07/03/two-union-soldiers-to-posthumously-receive-medal-of-honor-for-carrying-out-daring-mission-behind-confederate-lines/", "title": "Two Union soldiers to posthumously receive Medal of Honor for carrying out daring mission behind Confederate lines", "body": "(CNN) -- Two Union soldiers from the American Civil War are being posthumously awarded with the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on Wednesday, more than 160 years after being executed for their part in a daring mission against the Confederacy.\n\n\"Private Philip G. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson will receive the Medal of Honor posthumously for their gallantry and intrepidity while participating in a covert military operation 200 miles behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862,\" a White House official said. \"In one of the earliest special operations in US Army history, Union Soldiers dressed as civilians infiltrated the Confederacy, hijacked a train in Georgia and drove it north for 87 miles, destroying enemy infrastructure along the way.\"\n\nBiden will award the medals in a ceremony at the White House with descendants of Shadrach and Wilson expected to attend.\n\nThe pair were members of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment in 1862 when they joined 20 other Union soldiers, and two civilians, to infiltrate Confederate territory.\n\nThe raid, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, involved the soldiers commandeering a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\" The Confederates began chasing the General in handcars and locomotives, at some points even on foot, eventually catching up to them and forcing the Union soldiers to abandon it.\n\nThey were all captured within two weeks, and found guilty of \"acts of unlawful belligerency,\" according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nDr. Shane Makowicki, a US Army historian and expert in the American Civil War, told reporters that both Shadrach and Wilson were convicted as spies, and then executed by hanging.\n\n\"This is absolutely [a story] of intense dedication and commitment, intense bravery and comradery amongst the group of men that had only known each other for a short time, who believed in the mission and believed in the sacrifice and what they were doing to preserve the union,\" Kim Chandler, Wilson's great-great-great-granddaughter, told reporters on Tuesday.\n\nThe operation is now known as the Great Locomotive Chase. While other members of the raid received the Medal of Honor sooner -- six of whom after being released in a prisoner exchange in 1863 -- Brad Quinlan, another historian who assisted in the effort to get Shadrach and Wilson recognized, said bad timing was primarily to blame for the delay in Shadrach and Wilson's recognition. In the aftermath of the raid, he said, their officers were promoted into different units and moved on.\n\n\"It was just at that moment during our history, nobody was there to stand up for them and move this through, even their comrades who made the visits to Chattanooga and dedicated the monument to the Great Locomotive Chase in 1890, I don't think they even realized that these two men never had the medal. The paperwork never got through,\" Quinlan said.\n\n\"There was nothing anywhere in any of my research, any documentation that said these men did not do what the others have done,\" he added. \"Their bravery, their dignity, and their dedication to the Republic was exactly the same.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, Shadrach's great-great-great-nephew, told reporters the posthumous award is the culmination of \"a lot of very hard work\" for his family -- including efforts by his father to contact President Jimmy Carter.\n\n\"He was sending stuff to Jimmy Carter years ago, sometimes getting information back and sometimes getting ignored,\" Taylor said.\n\nQuinlan said he was pulled into the fight to get Shadrach and Wilson medals in April 2012 by Ron Shadrach, a great cousin of the Civil War private. In particular, the mission was to obliterate train tracks, bridges and telegraph wires between Atlanta, Georgia, and Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n\nToday, the Medal of Honor is the highest award for valor in the military. Jacob Parrott, who was severely tortured as a prisoner of war, became the very first recipient.\n\nThey also were offered commissions to serve as officers by the Union Secretary of War Edwin Stanton. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson, both of whom took part in the covert military operation 200 miles behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862, will be awarded the Medal of Honor for their \"gallantry and intrepidity,\" the White House official said in a statement.\n\nAlso known as the Andrews' Raid, the covert military operation is one of the earliest special operations in U.S. Army history.\n\nDuring the mission, a group of 24 Union soldiers called \"Andrew's Raiders\" disguised themselves as civilians and infiltrated the Confederacy; hijacking a Confederate train known as the \"General.\"\n\nThe group, led by civilian spy and scout James Andrews, then drove the train north for 87 miles toward the rebel stronghold of Chattanooga, Tennessee, destroying enemy infrastructure including railroad tracks and telegraph wires as they went.\n\nAfter running out of fuel, 20 of the group members were captured by Confederate troops. Eight members, including Private Shadrach and Private Wilson, were executed by hanging for their actions.\n\nHe was just 21 years old when he volunteered to take part in the Great Locomotive Chase mission.\n\nThe Civil War hero was \"willing to encounter both peril and hardship to fight for what he believed in\" and died while \"paying the ultimate sacrifice for his country,\" the White House said.\n\nPrivate Wilson, born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1830, was originally a tradesman who supported his family as a journeyman shoemaker but felt \"the call to serve his country,\" the White House said.\n\nHe enlisted in the Union Army's Company B, 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry, on August 31, 1861, for three years before volunteering for the Andrews' Raid.\n\nPrivate Wilson became a \"central figure\" in the Great Locomotive Chase, according to the White House official.\n\n\"Though Private Wilson tragically perished, his story remains inspiring,\" the official said.\n\nThe Medal of Honor, the highest military decoration, is awarded for acts of gallantry that distinguish an individual from his or her comrades. There must be incontestable proof of the performance of the meritorious conduct.\n\nSix of the Union soldiers who took part in the military operation became the Army's first-ever recipients of the Medal of Honor on March 25, 1863.\n\nIn total, 19 of the 24 participants in Andrews Raid eventually received the Medal of Honor.\n\nThe White House said it is unclear why Private Shadrach and Private Wilson were not originally recommended for the Medal of Honor, noting that both men deserved the award in 1863 for their actions during the mission.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", {"uri": "2024-07-410558059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "22:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T22:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T20:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/biden-award-medal-honor-civil-155011328.html", "title": "Biden awards Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later", "body": "Biden awards Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later\n\nCHRIS BOCCIA and NATE LUNA\n\nJuly 3, 2024 at 10:59 PM\n\nTwo Union soldiers who 162 years ago took part in one of America's first special operations were posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor on Wednesday.\n\nDescendants of Pvt. George Wilson and Pvt. Shadrach received a long-awaited call from the White House telling them the Civil War heroes would be awarded the nation's highest military honor for \"gallantry and intrepidity\" in defense of the Union.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was on the other line, they said, inviting Theresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Pvt. Wilson, and Gerald Taylor, the great-great-nephew of Pvt. Shadrach, to accept the medal on behalf of the men who, as a part of a group of 24 volunteers, snuck behind Confederate lines in an act of unprecedented bravery.\n\nThe Union soldiers -- acting as spies in civilian clothing -- managed to penetrate 200 miles into Confederate territory, where they commandeered a train -- \"The General\" -- and drove it 87 miles from Georgia to Tennessee.\n\nIn what became known as \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" on April 12, 1862, the Union raiders destroyed Confederate railroad tracks and telegraph lines -- earned 19 of the men Medals of Honor, becoming the first group of Army soldiers to receive it.\n\nThe ambitious plot, despite wreaking havoc, failed. The soldiers were captured. Some escaped and received their medals after the war, while a group of eight of the raiders -- including Wilson and Shadrach -- were tried and hanged by the Confederacy.\n\nBecause of what historians attribute to an oversight, Wilson and Shadrach never received the award posthumously.\n\nRon Shadrach, a descendant of Pvt. Shadrach, who was only 21 when he volunteered for the mission, and historian Brad Quinlin, teamed up to push Shadrach and Wilson's case. Text from a 2008 act of Congress even cleared the way for Wilson and Shadrach to be honored, but for reasons resembling \"red tape,\" some family said, the call simply never came.\n\nShadrach and Quinlin met in 2012 and made their case for 12 years, but even before them, a relative of Pvt. Shadrach was sending letters to President Jimmy Carter.\n\nAt the outset of the Biden Administration, two former generals -- one a four-star -- joined Shadrach and Quinlin's efforts.\n\nQuinlin believes the clandestine mission, which the White House describes as one of the first special operations in United States history, if successful, would have shortened the Civil War by as long as two years.\n\n\"I mean these were common citizens -- a laborer, a carpenter,\" he said.\n\n\"They enlisted. They weren't drafted; they enlisted voluntarily. And then all of a sudden you're getting the word, you know, we're asking for volunteers to come do what? Go in to a hundred miles of Confederate territory to steal a train. They stayed on. They were given a chance, they could have left after that, but they stayed on.\"\n\n\"I guess, unless we've really done it, do we really know what courage that took?\"\n\nBefore they were hanged, Pvt. Wilson is reported to have given a brief speech from the gallows in which he said he did not regret his action to help save the Union.\n\n\"He proclaimed that they would yet see the flag of the United States wave over them again,\" Ron Shadrack said.\n\nTwo years later, they would.\n\nShadrack labored over the case for more than 12 years to rectify the historical record, but, above all, he said, he did so in service of his ancestor's sacrifices.\n\n\"We can't really comprehend what they went through,\" the Ohio native said, a bout of imprisonment that including lashing and torture.\n\n\"I had wanted to serve my country, and I hadn't,\" Shadrack said. \"And so now I've been able to do this...\" he said, choking up, seemingly reckoning with this moment - a present day that would pay tribute to a day 162 years ago for which he has so long fought.\n\n\"And I think it's, it's something that any ordinary American would do,\" he said. \"It's what we do.\"\n\nQuinlin, who in his work has studied the acts of Medal of Honor recipients, said the award -- given to some 3,500 warfighters in U.S. history -- has documented the American story on the battlefield.\n\n\"I wouldn't have taken the project on if I didn't feel it was the right thing to do. I understand the Medal of Honor. I understand where it stands today with our military. And every military person looks up to a Medal of Honor recipients. Even generals take a seat to a Medal of Honor recipient,\" he said.\n\nA future Medal of Honor recipient saved Quinlin's father's life in the Philippines in World War II, losing his life as he fought off the Japanese.\n\n\"I am here because of what William Shockley did on March 31st, 1945. I understand the valor and sacrifice of the Medal of Honor,\" Quinlin said.\n\nBiden awards Medal of Honor to Civil War heroes, 162 years later originally appeared on abcnews.go.com", "source": The White House ceremony offered Biden a brief respite from the mounting criticism of some fellow Democrats after his shaky and halting performance in last week's presidential debate against Republican former President Donald Trump.\n\nPhilip Shadrach and George Wilson were honored posthumously during a White House ceremony that recognized their \"gallantry and intrepidity\" during what became known as the Great Locomotive Chase, one of the earliest special operations in U.S. Army history, according to the White House. Biden read remarks honoring the men's actions from a teleprompter and made no noticeable errors in delivery. His son, Hunter Biden, was in the audience.\n\nThe Civil War operation took place 200 miles (322 km) behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862. Union soldiers dressed as civilians commandeered a train and drove it north toward Chattanooga, Tennessee, placing explosives on the track behind them to destroy Confederate infrastructure. Six of those participants became the Army's first recipients of the then-newly created Medal of Honor. Shadrach and Wilson were both hanged for their actions after being captured. They were not previously given presidential honors.\n\n\"Today, we right that wrong,\" Biden said. \"Today, they finally receive the recognition they deserve.\" The Medal of Honor is awarded to military servicemembers who distinguish themselves at the risk of their own lives.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-410248468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "15:47:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T15:47:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:37:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/03/politics/medal-of-honor-union-soldiers/index.html", "title": "Two Union soldiers to posthumously receive Medal of Honor for carrying out daring mission behind Confederate lines | CNN Politics", "body": "In this illustration provided by the US Army, Union soldiers cut telegraph wires and commandeered a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga in April 1862. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\"\n\nCNN --\n\nTwo Union soldiers from the American Civil War are being posthumously awarded with the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on Wednesday, more than 160 years after being executed for their part in a daring mission against the Confederacy.\n\n\"Private Philip G. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson will receive the Medal of Honor posthumously for their gallantry and intrepidity while participating in a covert military operation 200 miles behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862,\" a White House official said. \"In one of the earliest special operations in US Army history, Union Soldiers dressed as civilians infiltrated the Confederacy, hijacked a train in Georgia and drove it north for 87 miles, destroying enemy infrastructure along the way.\"\n\nBiden will award the medals in a ceremony at the White House with descendants of Shadrach and Wilson expected to attend.\n\nThe pair were members of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment in 1862 when they joined 20 other Union soldiers, and two civilians, to infiltrate Confederate territory.\n\nThe raid, according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, involved the soldiers commandeering a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\" The Confederates began chasing the General in handcars and locomotives, at some points even on foot, eventually catching up to them and forcing the Union soldiers to abandon it.\n\nThey were all captured within two weeks, and found guilty of \"acts of unlawful belligerency,\" according to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society.\n\nIn this illustration provided by the US Army, Union soldiers tear up a track while commandeering a locomotive known as the General that was on its way toward Chattanooga in April 1862. They would stop occasionally along the route to \"tear up track, switches, and bridges, inflicting as much damage as possible.\"\n\nUS Army\n\nDr. Shane Makowicki, a US Army historian and expert in the American Civil War, told reporters that both Shadrach and Wilson were convicted as spies, and then executed by hanging.\n\n\"This is absolutely [a story] of intense dedication and commitment, intense bravery and comradery amongst the group of men that had only known each other for a short time, who believed in the mission and believed in the sacrifice and what they were doing to preserve the union,\" Kim Chandler, Wilson's great-great-great-granddaughter, told reporters on Tuesday.\n\nThe operation is now known as the Great Locomotive Chase. While other members of the raid received the Medal of Honor sooner -- six of whom after being released in a prisoner exchange in 1863 -- Brad Quinlan, another historian who assisted in the effort to get Shadrach and Wilson recognized, said bad timing was primarily to blame for the delay in Shadrach and Wilson's recognition. In the aftermath of the raid, he said, their officers were promoted into different units and moved on.\n\n\"It was just at that moment during our history, nobody was there to stand up for them and move this through, even their comrades who made the visits to Chattanooga and dedicated the monument to the Great Locomotive Chase in 1890, I don't think they even realized that these two men never had the medal. The paperwork never got through,\" Quinlan said.\n\n\"There was nothing anywhere in any of my research, any documentation that said these men did not do what the others have done,\" he added. \"Their bravery, their dignity, and their dedication to the Republic was exactly the same.\"\n\nBrian Taylor, Shadrach's great-great-great-nephew, told reporters the posthumous award is the culmination of \"a lot of very hard work\" for his family -- including efforts by his father to contact President Jimmy Carter.\n\n\"He was sending stuff to Jimmy Carter years ago, sometimes getting information back and sometimes getting ignored,\" Taylor said.\n\nQuinlan said he was pulled into the fight to get Shadrach and Wilson medals in April 2012 by Ron Shadrach, a great cousin of the Civil War private. It took 12 years of \"researching, finding new documents, primary sources, and submitting the documentation,\" he said.\n\n\"It was just something that needed to be done,\" Ron Shadrach said.", {"uri": "8207581892", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "10:32:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T10:32:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T10:32:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.militarytimes.com/newsletters/daily-news-roundup/2024/07/03/civil-war-soldiers-to-get-medal-of-honor-for-confederate-train-raid/", "title": "Civil War soldiers to get Medal of Honor for Confederate train raid", "body": "Two Civil War soldiers who infiltrated Confederate territory to steal a train and destroy the enemy railroad system will be posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on Wednesday.\n\nPvt. Philip Shadrach and Pvt. George Wilson, members of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment, are finally set to receive recognition as participants in what is known as the \"Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nOn April 12, 1862, the pair joined 20 other Union soldiers and two civilians in commandeering a train in Georgia, before driving it north while demolishing Confederate railroad tracks and telegraph lines. Both men were captured and executed by hanging.\n\nNow, 162 years later, the soldiers are being recognized for their previously overlooked contributions to an event that others were awarded Medals of Honor for -- including Pvt. Jacob Parrott, the very first service member to be presented with the military's highest award for valor.\n\n\"It touches me deeply,\" Theresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, said Tuesday at a media event. \"I just get so emotional with it, thinking he had such bravery and valor.\"\n\nThe plan was straightforward. By sabotaging the Western and Atlantic Railroad, the men would cut off the Confederacy's ability to move supplies or reinforcements from Atlanta, Georgia, to Chattanooga, Tennessee, and deprive them of making strategic advances. Shadrach, Wilson and the others met in Big Shanty, now Kennesaw, Georgia, where they took over a locomotive known as the \"General\" and implemented their operation. But the Confederates caught up, and captured the raiders.\n\n\"More than anything else, it is the story of American soldiers far from home committing extraordinary acts of service and bravery on behalf of their country,\" said Dr. Shane Makowicki, a historian from the Army Center of Military History.\n\nHe and another historian explained that whether it was an initial oversight in the documentation process or a lack of individuals advocating on their behalf, the bravery of Shadrach and Wilson was exactly the same as the other men who participated, most of whom received the Medal of Honor for their actions.\n\n\"It was just, at that moment during our history, nobody was there to stand up for them and move this through,\" said Brad Quinlin, a historian and author, who also suggested that one of the reasons for the delay may have been that their infantry regiment was decimated in another battle, leaving few who could push for them to receive the distinction.\n\nApproval to bestow the decorations on the soldiers came in the fiscal year 2008 annual defense policy bill, though it still took time to get the paperwork in the right hands and across the finish line.\n\nBut, not everyone involved in the risky undertaking has received recognition for their actions.\n\nJames Andrews -- the leader of the group, which became known as Andrews' Raiders -- and William Campbell were not eligible for the Medal of Honor as civilians, though Quinlin said he's working on requests to get them awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.\n\nAdditionally, one remaining soldier involved in the group, Samuel Llewellyn, does not hold the country's highest military decoration. According to Quinlin, he turned it down, thinking he did not deserve it as he was caught before reaching the rendezvous point.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are buried at Chattanooga National Cemetery in Tennessee, Quinlin shared with Military Times.\n\nKimberly Chandler, a great-great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, described the story of her ancestor as \"one of intense dedication and commitment, intense bravery and camaraderie amongst a group of men that had only known each other for a short time, believed in the mission and believed in the sacrifice of what they were doing to preserve the {"uri": "8208130694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "16:04:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T16:04:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T16:03:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/biden-to-award-medal-of-honor-posthumously-to-2-civil-war-heroes_1002846.html", "title": "Biden to Award Medal of Honor Posthumously to 2 Civil War Heroes", "body": "President Joe Biden arrives for a news conference at the White House on July 1, 2024.(Andrew Harnik/Getty Images)\n\nTwo soldiers who were executed for their role in the Great Locomotive Chase in northern Georgia during the American Civil War will be posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on July 3, according to a White House official.\n\nPrivate Philip G. Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson, both of whom took part in the covert military operation 200 miles behind Confederate lines on April 12, 1862, will be awarded the Medal of Honor for their \"gallantry and intrepidity,\" the White House official said in a statement.\n\nAlso known as the Andrews' Raid, the covert military operation is one of the earliest special operations in U.S. Army history.\n\nDuring the mission, a group of 24 Union soldiers called \"Andrew's Raiders\" disguised themselves as civilians and infiltrated the Confederacy; hijacking a Confederate train known as the \"General.\"\n\nThe group, led by civilian spy and scout James Andrews, then drove the train north for 87 miles toward the rebel stronghold of Chattanooga, Tennessee, destroying enemy infrastructure including railroad tracks and telegraph wires as they went.\n\nAfter running out of fuel, 20 of the group members were captured by Confederate troops. Eight members, including Private Shadrach and Private Wilson, were executed by hanging for their actions.\n\nThe remaining men were imprisoned.\n\nPrivate Shadrach, a native Pennsylvanian, was born in Somerset County on September 15, 1840, and enlisted in the Union Army's Company K of the 2nd Ohio Infantry Regiment on September 20, 1861, for three years, according to the Biden administration.\n\nHe was 21 years old when he volunteered to take part in the Great Locomotive Chase mission.\n\nThe Civil War hero was \"willing to encounter both peril and hardship to fight for what he believed in\" and died while \"paying the ultimate sacrifice for his country,\" the White House said.\n\nPrivate Wilson, born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1830, was originally a tradesman who supported his family as a journeyman shoemaker but felt \"the call to serve his country,\" the White House said.\n\nHe enlisted in the Union Army's Company B, 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry, on August 31, 1861, for three years before volunteering for the Andrews' Raid.\n\nPrivate Wilson became a \"central figure\" in the Great Locomotive Chase, according to the White House official.\n\n\"Though Private Wilson tragically perished, his story remains inspiring,\" the official said.\n\nThe Medal of Honor, the highest military decoration, is awarded for acts of gallantry that distinguish an individual from his or her comrades. There must be incontestable proof of the performance of the meritorious conduct.\n\nSix of the Union soldiers who took part in the military operation became the Army's first-ever recipients of the Medal of Honor on March 25, 1863.\n\nIn total, 19 of the 24 participants in Andrews Raid eventually received the Medal of Honor.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, {"uri": "8208121415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "15:58:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T15:58:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T15:57:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/news/2024/07/president-biden-to-give-two-ohio-civil-war-soldiers-the-medal-of-honor-for-role-in-great-locomotive-chase.html", "title": "President Biden to give two Ohio Civil War soldiers the Medal of Honor for role in 'Great Locomotive Chase'", "body": "WASHINGTON, D. C. - The year was 1862. With the Civil War in full throttle, around two dozen Union Army soldiers from Ohio snuck onto Confederate territory with a bold plan to destroy enemy supply lines and infrastructure between Atlanta, Georgia and Chattanooga, Tennessee before a Union attack on Chattanooga.\n\nThe group, known as \"Andrews' Raiders\" because it was led by a civilian spy named James J. Andrews, commandeered a locomotive known as the General near Kennesaw, Georgia, on April 12, 1862, and drove it north along the Western and Atlantic Railroad line for around seven hours, destroying telegraph lines and railroad tracks along the way.\n\nWhen the train ran out of fuel near Ringgold, Georgia, the Ohioans scattered and were apprehended by Confederate troops. Eight of them, including Andrews, were executed as spies. The rest escaped or were exchanged for Confederate prisoners.\n\nFor their role in what became known as \"The Great Locomotive Chase,\" which later became the subject of a 1956 Disney film, six of the Ohioans were awarded the nation's first Medals of Honor. All but two of the non-civilian raid participants subsequently got the award, which is given to members of the Armed Forces who distinguish themselves conspicuously by gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of their own lives above and beyond the call of duty.\n\nOn Wednesday, President Joe Biden will award the nation's highest military honor to the remaining Ohio soldiers who didn't previously get the award: Private Philip Gephardt Shadrach and Private George D. Wilson. Both were hanged as spies in Atlanta on June 18,1862. They're buried in Chattanooga National Cemetery.\n\nShadrach, a Pennsylvania native who was orphaned at an early age, moved to Ohio before enlisting in Company K of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment out of Jefferson County. Also known as Charles Perry Shadrach, he was 21 when he died.\n\nWilson, a Belmont County native who served in Company B of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment out of Warren County, was in his early 30s when the raid happened. Before enlisting, he was a tradesman who supported his family as a journeyman shoemaker.\n\nA White House official said it's unknown why the pair were initially overlooked for the medal they deserved.\n\nRelatives of the two men will pick up their awards, which were authorized by language in a 2008 defense bill to correct the historic error. Former U.S. Rep. Dave Hobson, a Springfield Republican, said he introduced the measure at the request of a constituent.\n\nA statement from Hobson said he was disappointed it took the Army so long to rectify the mistake, but glad Shadrach and Wilson would finally get the honors they deserve, thanks to his efforts and those of U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown, a Cleveland Democrat.\n\n\"In a time when we see so much divisiveness, the bipartisan commitment to do the right thing and honor these two soldiers with the Medal of Honor can hopefully remind us of the value of national unity and that when we come together as Americans, we can do anything,\" Hobson's statement said.\n\nBrown said his work to correct the historical record required engaging the Secretary of the Army, the Secretary of Defense, and ultimately the President. He said he's been on the case since 2015.\n\n\"Privates Shadrach and Wilson heroically served our nation during the Civil War, making the ultimate sacrifice to protect the Union - but because of a clerical error, they never received the Medal of Honor they each earned,\" said a statement from Brown.\n\nRon Shadrach of Independence, a cousin of the dead soldier who has long lobbied for the award and established a website that describes Shadrach and Wilson's heroism, travelled to Washington for the ceremony. He says he first found out about Private Shadrach's historic role when he visited relatives in the Columbus area as an elementary schooler, and they showed him a plaque at Ohio's statehouse with the names of Ohioans who took part in the historic raid.\n\nIn 2003, he saw an article about the drive to get medals for Shadrach and Wilson and decided to research how he was connected to the Civil War hero. He learned that the soldier's grandparents, Robert and Eleanor Shadrach, were his own great-great-great-grandparents. He began writing letters to Congress members from Ohio, Pennsylvania, Georgia and Tennessee to draw attention to the medals drive, and submitted research to the Defense Department.\n\n\"I am thrilled,\" said Shadrach. \"I can't overstate how exciting this is. I hope that through it, people read their story and understand what these fellows and their comrades went through during that time in our nation's history.\"", "source": {"uri": "cleveland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cleveland"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadrach_(Beastie_Boys_song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Shadrach (Beastie Boys song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Army", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Union Army"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Confederate States of America"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ohio"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Ohio"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chattanooga,_Tennessee", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chattanooga, Tennessee"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chattanooga, Tennessee"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Andrews", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "James J. {"uri": "2024-07-410996071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "09:05:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T09:05:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T10:21:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.armytimes.com/news/your-army/2024/07/03/civil-war-soldiers-awarded-medal-of-honor-for-confederate-train-raid/", "title": "Civil War soldiers awarded Medal of Honor for Confederate train raid", "body": "Civil War soldiers Pvt. Philip Shadrach, left, and Pvt. George Wilson, right, will be posthumously presented the Medal of Honor for their roles in the \"Great Locomotive Chase\" that took place in 1862. (Army)\n\nTwo Civil War soldiers who infiltrated Confederate territory to steal a train and destroy the enemy railroad system were posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor by President Joe Biden on Wednesday.\n\nPvt. Philip Shadrach and Pvt. George Wilson, members of the 2nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regiment, are finally set to receive recognition as participants in what is known as the \"Great Locomotive Chase.\"\n\nOn April 12, 1862, the pair joined 20 other Union soldiers and two civilians in commandeering a train in Georgia, before driving it north while demolishing Confederate railroad tracks and telegraph lines. Both men were captured and executed by hanging.\n\nNow, 162 years later, the soldiers are being recognized for their previously overlooked contributions to an event that others were awarded Medals of Honor for -- including Pvt. Jacob Parrott, the very first service member to be presented with the military's highest award for valor.\n\n\"It touches me deeply,\" Theresa Chandler, the great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, said Tuesday at a media event. \"I just get so emotional with it, thinking he had such bravery and valor.\"\n\nThe plan was straightforward. By sabotaging the Western and Atlantic Railroad, the men would cut off the Confederacy's ability to move supplies or reinforcements from Atlanta, Georgia, to Chattanooga, Tennessee, and deprive them of making strategic advances. Shadrach, Wilson and the others met in Big Shanty, now Kennesaw, Georgia, where they took over a locomotive known as the \"General\" and implemented their operation. But the Confederates caught up, and captured the raiders.\n\n\"More than anything else, it is the story of American soldiers far from home committing extraordinary acts of service and bravery on behalf of their country,\" said Dr. Shane Makowicki, a historian from the Army Center of Military History.\n\nHe and another historian explained that whether it was an initial oversight in the documentation process or a lack of individuals advocating on their behalf, the bravery of Shadrach and Wilson was exactly the same as the other men who participated, most of whom received the Medal of Honor for their actions.\n\n\"It was just, at that moment during our history, nobody was there to stand up for them and move this through,\" said Brad Quinlin, a historian and author, who also suggested that one of the reasons for the delay may have been that their infantry regiment was decimated in another battle, leaving few who could push for them to receive the distinction.\n\nApproval to bestow the decorations on the soldiers came in the fiscal year 2008 annual defense policy bill, though it still took time to get the paperwork in the right hands and across the finish line.\n\nBut, not everyone involved in the risky undertaking has received recognition for their actions.\n\nJames Andrews -- the leader of the group, which became known as Andrews' Raiders -- and William Campbell were not eligible for the Medal of Honor as civilians, though Quinlin said he's working on requests to get them awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.\n\nAdditionally, one remaining soldier involved in the group, Samuel Llewellyn, does not hold the country's highest military decoration. According to Quinlin, he turned it down, thinking he did not deserve it as he was caught before reaching the rendezvous point.\n\nShadrach and Wilson are buried at Chattanooga National Cemetery in Tennessee, Quinlin shared with Military Times.\n\nKimberly Chandler, a great-great-great-granddaughter of Wilson, described the story of her ancestor as \"one of intense dedication and commitment, intense bravery and camaraderie amongst a group of men that had only known each other for a short time, believed in the mission and believed in the sacrifice of what they were doing to preserve the
